questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-day history of pain in his right great toe. The patient says that the pain has been worsening over the past few days and that he has difficulty wearing shoes and walking. Medical history is remarkable for asthma treated with a corticosteroid inhaler as needed. Examination of the right great toe shows growth of the nail plate into the lateral periungual skin, with sharply demarcated areas of erythema and swelling around the nail. There is severe tenderness around the toe without fluctuation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical antifungal therapy (e.g., terbinafine) is indicated for tinea pedis, which typically manifest with erythema and occasionally with painful lesions. However, tinea pedis is characterized by pruritic, erythematous erosions or scales between the toes. Antifungals are not used in the management of ingrown toenails.
Image Description:

Pronounced, well-demarcated erythema with scaling is visible between the third and fourth toes.

This appearance is typical of tinea pedis, which typically manifests with severe pruritus.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids are used in the conservative treatment of ingrown toenails. However, conservative measures are insufficient to treat the severe inflammation in this patient. Additionally, ice packing is not indicated for ingrown toenails. Instead, patients should soak the affected toe in warm soapy water.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotic therapy is indicated for ingrown toenails with cellulitis, which can manifest with swelling, erythema, and pain. However, cellulitis manifests with a poorly defined rather than a sharply demarcated lesion. Topical antibiotic therapy can be used in patients without signs of severe inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage are indicated for toenail paronychia with abscess, which can manifest with worsening pain, erythema, and swelling. Unlike this patient's presentation, an abscess manifests as a fluctuating mass due to purulent fluid collection.

E) CORRECT:

Surgical treatment is indicated for ingrown toenails with severe inflammation and/or infection, for recurrent ingrown toenails, or if conservative measures are unsuccessful. Partial nail avulsion with chemical matricectomy is the preferred technique. Ingrown toenails with mild to moderate inflammation may be treated with conservative measures (e.g., cotton or gutter nail cast, taping, topical corticosteroids), which reduce contact between the nail plate and nail fold, thereby reducing inflammation and pain. Preventive measures include proper trimming of the nails, appropriate footwear, and good foot hygiene.
Image Description:

The hallux toenail has grown into the subcutaneous tissue. The skin around the nail matrix is erythematous and swollen, and the surface is shiny. There are signs of pus discharge and bleeding.
questions.hint: The patient presents with an ingrown toenail with a sharply demarcated area of erythema, swelling, and pain, indicating severe inflammation. The most important risk factor for this condition is improper nail trimming.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of pain in her right index finger. She does not recall injuring her finger but the pain has become progressively worse and over the past 4 days, the painful area has become slightly swollen and red. She works as a bartender at a local bar. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/75 mm Hg. Examination of the right index finger shows an erythematous, swollen, and tender lateral nail fold; the nail plate and nail bed appear normal. When light pressure is applied to the volar aspect of the fingertip, a well-demarcated, fluctuating area of blanching appears in the lateral nail fold. The remainder of the physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Soaks with warm water and 1% acetic acid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Soaks with warm water and 1% acetic acid are appropriate first-line therapy for patients with acute paronychia who do not have an abscess. This patient's positive digital pressure test indicates an abscess, which warrants another treatment modality.

B) CORRECT:

Incision and drainage (I&D) is the treatment of choice for acute paronychia if an abscess is present. Antibiotic therapy following I&D is only warranted in patients with immunosuppression or overlying cellulitis. If an abscess is not present, management of acute paronychia includes elevation, soaking the affected digit in warm water 2–4 times daily, and topical antibiotics (e.g., mupirocin). Complications of this infection include development of felon, osteomyelitis, or chronic paronychia.

Risk factors for acute paronychia include professions involving manual labor in which trauma to the nail folds or exposure to moisture may occur (such as a bartender).
Image Description:

Characteristic finding of paronychia: Periungual erythema and pus lateral to the nail.

C) INCORRECT:

Eponychial marsupialization is a surgical technique that is sometimes used to treat chronic paronychia. Eponychial marsupialization is not used in the treatment of acute paronychia and even in patients with chronic paronychia, this procedure is not a recommended first-line therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics (e.g., mupirocin) are an appropriate first-line therapy and topical corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone) are an appropriate adjunctive therapy for patients with acute paronychia without abscess. This patient's positive digital pressure test indicates an abscess, which warrants another treatment modality.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotic therapy (e.g., dicloxacillin, cephalexin, amoxicillin/clavulanate) is only indicated for the treatment of acute paronychia if patients do not respond to topical therapy alone, have overlying cellulitis, or are immunocompromised.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical features and the duration of symptoms (< 6 weeks) are consistent with acute paronychia. A positive digital pressure test indicates an abscess.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents with a throbbing sensation in the ring finger of his right hand. Two days earlier, he removed a hangnail, prompting redness that has worsened significantly despite soaking his finger in warm water and applying an over-the-counter topical antibiotic. He says that he has not been biting or sucking on his fingers.
He is afebrile. The lateral nail fold of the affected finger exhibits significant edema with surrounding erythema extending to the distal interphalangeal joint (figure).
What is the optimal management approach for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Incision and drainage plus oral cephalexin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

When the infection does not respond to incision and drainage, or when there are indications of more extensive involvement of the hand or cellulitis (as in this case), oral antibiotic therapy is often added. The use of an oral antibiotic such as cephalexin alone would be insufficient.

B) CORRECT:

Acute paronychia is typically caused by acute penetrating trauma, such as nail biting, aggressive manicuring, or hangnail removal. Warm compresses or soaks along with topical antibacterial agents, such as mupirocin, may be sufficient for mild cases of paronychia. If an abscess has formed, as in this case, surgical incision and drainage is the definitive treatment. When the infection does not respond to incision and drainage, or when there are indications of more extensive involvement of the hand or cellulitis (as in this case), oral antibiotic therapy is often added.

Staphylococcus aureus and streptococci are the most common organisms that cause paronychia when other risk factors (finger sucking, nail biting, comorbidities) are not present. In patients who bite or suck on their fingers, mouth flora (such as Eikenella corrodens, Hemophilus influenza, and oral anaerobic bacteria) may also be involved, and treatment with a broad-spectrum antibiotic, such as amoxicillin-clavulanate, may be necessary. If antibiotic therapy is given, coverage for methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) with a drug such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should be considered in areas where MRSA is common or in patients with risk factors for resistant infection.

Key learning point: The optimal way to manage acute paronychia with abscess of the finger and surrounding cellulitis is incision and drainage plus oral antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Antifungal therapy, such as oral fluconazole, is not indicated for acute paronychia.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids, such as hydrocortisone, are not routinely indicated for the treatment of acute paronychia.

E) INCORRECT:

Warm compresses or soaks along with topical antibacterial agents, such as mupirocin, may be sufficient for mild cases of paronychia. If an abscess has formed, as in this case, the use of a topical antibiotic and warm compresses alone would be insufficient.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 13-year-old boy presents with a throbbing sensation in his second finger. Two days ago, he removed a hangnail, prompting redness that has worsened significantly despite his mother soaking his finger in warm water and applying an over-the-counter topical antibiotic. He says that he occasionally bites his fingernails.
He is afebrile. His lateral nail fold exhibits significant edema with surrounding erythema extending to the distal interphalangeal joint (figure).
What is the optimal management approach for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Incision and drainage followed by warm soaks or compresses
Incision and drainage plus oral amoxicillin-clavulanate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment depends on the severity of the inflammation and the presence or absence of abscess. Warm soaks or compresses may be sufficient for mild cases of paronychia. However, if an abscess has formed, as in this case, surgical incision and drainage is definitive treatment; if there is cellulitis or more extensive involvement of the hand, then oral antibiotic therapy is also indicated. In this case, the erythema extending to the distal interphalangeal joint is evidence of cellulitis requiring systemic antibiotic therapy in addition to incision and drainage.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids, such as hydrocortisone, are not routinely indicated for the treatment of acute paronychia.

C) CORRECT:

Acute paronychia is typically caused by acute penetrating trauma, such as nail biting, aggressive manicuring, or hangnail removal. It is characterized by rapid onset of swelling and erythema around the proximal and lateral nail folds.

Treatment depends on the severity of the inflammation and the presence or absence of abscess. Warm soaks or compresses may be sufficient for mild cases of paronychia. However, if an abscess has formed, as in this case, surgical incision and drainage is definitive treatment; if there is cellulitis or more extensive involvement of the hand, then oral antibiotic therapy is also indicated. In this case, the erythema extending to the distal interphalangeal joint is evidence of cellulitis requiring systemic antibiotic therapy in addition to incision and drainage.

The choice of antibiotic therapy depends on whether the patient has risk factors for paronychia, including finger sucking, nail biting, and certain comorbidities. Staphylococcus aureus and streptococci are the most common organisms that cause paronychia when such risk factors are not present. For these patients, cephalexin would provide appropriate empiric coverage with or without incision and drainage, depending on the presence of an abscess. In patients who suck on their fingers or bite their nails, as in this case, mouth flora (such as Eikenella corrodens, Haemophilus influenzae, and oral anaerobic bacteria) may be involved, and treatment with a broad-spectrum antibiotic, such as amoxicillin-clavulanate, may be necessary.

If antibiotic therapy is given, coverage for methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) with a drug such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should be considered in areas where MRSA is common or in patients with risk factors for resistant infection.

The use of an oral antibiotic alone, without surgical incision and drainage, would be insufficient for paronychia with abscess.

Key learning point: The optimal way to manage acute paronychia with abscess of the finger and surrounding cellulitis in a patient who bites their nails or sucks their fingers is incision and drainage plus oral antibiotics to cover oral flora.

D) INCORRECT:

The choice of antibiotic therapy depends on whether the patient has risk factors for paronychia, including finger sucking, nail biting, and certain comorbidities. Staphylococcus aureus and streptococci are the most common organisms that cause paronychia when such risk factors are not present. For these patients, cephalexin would provide appropriate empiric coverage with or without incision and drainage, depending on the presence of an abscess.

E) INCORRECT:

Antiviral therapy with oral acyclovir is indicated for treatment of herpetic whitlow (an infection of a digit due to herpes simplex virus), but not for acute paronychia. A herpetic whitlow develops after inoculation of the skin from an oral herpes simplex lesion and can be confused with an acute bacterial infection, but the viral infection does not cause abscess formation.

For these patients, cephalexin would provide appropriate empiric coverage with or without incision and drainage, depending on the presence of an abscess.

A herpetic whitlow develops after inoculation of the skin from an oral herpes simplex lesion and can be confused with an acute bacterial infection, but the viral infection does not cause abscess formation.

She does not recall injuring her finger but the pain has become progressively worse and over the past 4 days. She works as a bartender at a local bar. A) INCORRECT:

B) CORRECT:

If an abscess is not present, management of acute paronychia includes elevation, soaking the affected digit in warm water 2–4 times daily, and topical antibiotics (e.g., mupirocin). Complications of this infection include development of felon, osteomyelitis, or chronic paronychia.

Risk factors for acute paronychia include professions involving manual labor in which trauma to the nail folds or exposure to moisture may occur (such as a bartender).

Characteristic finding of paronychia: Periungual erythema and pus lateral to the nail.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-day history of pain in his right great toe. He reports that the pain has worsened over the past few days, making it difficult to wear shoes and walk. His medical history includes asthma, for which he uses a corticosteroid inhaler as needed. On examination, the right great toe shows the nail plate growing into the lateral periungual skin, with sharply demarcated erythema and swelling around the nail. There is severe tenderness around the toe, but no fluctuation. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage are indicated for toenail paronychia with abscess, which can manifest with worsening pain, erythema, and swelling. Unlike this patient's presentation, an abscess manifests as a fluctuating mass due to purulent fluid collection.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids are used in the conservative treatment of ingrown toenails. However, conservative measures are insufficient to treat the severe inflammation in this patient. Additionally, ice packing is not indicated for ingrown toenails. Instead, patients should soak the affected toe in warm soapy water.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotic therapy is indicated for ingrown toenails with cellulitis, which can manifest with swelling, erythema, and pain. However, cellulitis manifests with a poorly defined rather than a sharply demarcated lesion. Topical antibiotic therapy can be used in patients without signs of severe inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical antifungal therapy (e.g., terbinafine) is indicated for tinea pedis, which typically manifest with erythema and occasionally with painful lesions. However, tinea pedis is characterized by pruritic, erythematous erosions or scales between the toes. Antifungals are not used in the management of ingrown toenails.

E) CORRECT:

Surgical treatment is indicated for ingrown toenails with severe inflammation and/or infection, for recurrent ingrown toenails, or if conservative measures are unsuccessful. Partial nail avulsion with chemical matricectomy is the preferred technique. Ingrown toenails with mild to moderate inflammation may be treated with conservative measures (e.g., cotton or gutter nail cast, taping, topical corticosteroids), which reduce contact between the nail plate and nail fold, thereby reducing inflammation and pain. Preventive measures include proper trimming of the nails, appropriate footwear, and good foot hygiene.

Key learning point: Severe ingrown toenails with marked inflammation are best managed by partial nail avulsion with chemical matricectomy rather than conservative or antibiotic therapy.
Image Description:

The hallux toenail has grown into the subcutaneous tissue. The skin around the nail matrix is erythematous and swollen, and the surface is shiny. There are signs of pus discharge and bleeding.
questions.hint: The patient presents with an ingrown toenail with a sharply demarcated area of erythema, swelling, and pain, indicating severe inflammation. The most important risk factor for this condition is improper nail trimming.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 13-year-old boy who presents with a throbbing sensation in his second finger. Two days ago, he removed a hangnail, after which redness developed and has worsened despite his mother soaking the finger in warm water and applying an over-the-counter topical antibiotic. He reports occasionally biting his fingernails. He is afebrile. On examination, the lateral nail fold shows significant edema with surrounding erythema extending to the distal interphalangeal joint (see figure). Which one of the following is the optimal management approach for this condition?

choices.text: Incision and drainage followed by warm soaks or compresses.
Incision and drainage plus oral amoxicillin-clavulanate.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment depends on the severity of the inflammation and the presence or absence of abscess. Warm soaks or compresses may be sufficient for mild cases of paronychia. However, if an abscess has formed, as in this case, surgical incision and drainage is definitive treatment; if there is cellulitis or more extensive involvement of the hand, then oral antibiotic therapy is also indicated. In this case, the erythema extending to the distal interphalangeal joint is evidence of cellulitis requiring systemic antibiotic therapy in addition to incision and drainage.

A herpetic whitlow develops after inoculation of the skin from an oral herpes simplex lesion and can be confused with an acute bacterial infection, but the viral infection does not cause abscess formation.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids, such as hydrocortisone, are not routinely indicated for the treatment of acute paronychia.

D) CORRECT:

Acute paronychia is typically caused by acute penetrating trauma, such as nail biting, aggressive manicuring, or hangnail removal. It is characterized by rapid onset of swelling and erythema around the proximal and lateral nail folds.

Treatment depends on the severity of the inflammation and the presence or absence of abscess. Warm soaks or compresses may be sufficient for mild cases of paronychia. However, if an abscess has formed, as in this case, surgical incision and drainage is definitive treatment; if there is cellulitis or more extensive involvement of the hand, then oral antibiotic therapy is also indicated. In this case, the erythema extending to the distal interphalangeal joint is evidence of cellulitis requiring systemic antibiotic therapy in addition to incision and drainage.

The choice of antibiotic therapy depends on whether the patient has risk factors for paronychia, including finger sucking, nail biting, and certain comorbidities. Staphylococcus aureus and streptococci are the most common organisms that cause paronychia when such risk factors are not present. For these patients, cephalexin would provide appropriate empiric coverage with or without incision and drainage, depending on the presence of an abscess. In patients who suck on their fingers or bite their nails, as in this case, mouth flora (such as Eikenella corrodens, Haemophilus influenzae, and oral anaerobic bacteria) may be involved, and treatment with a broad-spectrum antibiotic, such as amoxicillin-clavulanate, may be necessary.

If antibiotic therapy is given, coverage for methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) with a drug such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should be considered in areas where MRSA is common or in patients with risk factors for resistant infection.

The use of an oral antibiotic alone, without surgical incision and drainage, would be insufficient for paronychia with abscess.

Key learning point: The optimal way to manage acute paronychia with abscess of the finger and surrounding cellulitis in a patient who bites their nails or sucks their fingers is incision and drainage plus oral antibiotics to cover oral flora.

E) INCORRECT:

The choice of antibiotic therapy depends on whether the patient has risk factors for paronychia, including finger sucking, nail biting, and certain comorbidities. Staphylococcus aureus and streptococci are the most common organisms that cause paronychia when such risk factors are not present. For these patients, cephalexin would provide appropriate empiric coverage with or without incision and drainage, depending on the presence of an abscess.

questions.text: A 28-year-old carpenter presents with a 2-day history of increasing pain and swelling of his right index finger after a minor puncture wound from a splinter. The finger is warm, erythematous, and tender to palpation at the fingertip without fluctuance or pallor. He reports the pain is worse when his hand is dependent. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Topical mupirocin and warm water soaks
Incision and drainage of the nail fold

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical presentation of fingertip pain and swelling following puncture trauma suggests early felon. Initial management includes oral antibiotics with staphylococcal coverage such as cephalexin or amoxicillin/clavulanic acid. Surgical intervention is reserved for patients with established abscess formation.

B) INCORRECT:

Digital block and longitudinal incision are performed for felon with established abscess and fluctuance. This procedure is not indicated in early stages of infection without clear abscess formation, as conservative management with antibiotics may be sufficient.

C) INCORRECT:

Hand surgery referral is appropriate for complex cases, established abscesses requiring drainage, or complications. Initial management of early felon involves oral antibiotics and close follow-up before surgical consultation.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical mupirocin and warm water soaks are appropriate for acute paronychia without abscess formation. This patient's clinical presentation and location of the infection on the fingertip suggest a deeper infection requiring systemic antibiotics.

E) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage of the nail fold is the treatment for acute paronychia with abscess formation. The fingertip location and history of puncture wound suggest pulp space infection rather than nail fold involvement.

questions.text: A 45-year-old restaurant dishwasher presents with a 3-day history of progressively worsening pain and swelling around her left thumbnail. Examination is shown. The patient is afebrile with normal vital signs. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical steroids such as triamcinolone are indicated for chronic paronychia caused by irritant exposure. This patient has acute paronychia with abscess formation, which requires surgical drainage rather than anti-inflammatory treatment.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation (fluctuance, swelling, pain, visible pus collection) is consistent with acute paronychia with an abscess, which requires incision and drainage.

C) INCORRECT:

Hand surgery referral is not required for uncomplicated acute paronychia with abscess. Simple incision and drainage can be performed in the emergency department or clinic setting. Referral is reserved for complications or refractory chronic cases.

D) INCORRECT:

While topical mupirocin may be appropriate for mild acute paronychia without abscess formation, the presence of fluctuance and pus collection requires incision and drainage. Topical antibiotics alone are insufficient to treat an abscess.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics are not the primary treatment for acute paronychia with a localized abscess. While they may be used as adjunctive therapy in patients with concurrent cellulitis, severe illness, or immunocompromise, the most appropriate initial management is source control through incision and drainage of the abscess.

questions.text: A 35-year-old carpenter presents with a 4-day history of progressive finger pain following a wood splinter injury. Examination of the affected area is shown. What is the most appropriate management approach?

choices.text: Oral antibiotics with staphylococcal coverage and conservative measures
Incision and drainage with oral antibiotics

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics are insufficient for felon treatment, which requires systemic antibiotics with staphylococcal coverage. The presence of a visible pus collection indicates the need for surgical drainage.

B) INCORRECT:

Conservative management with antibiotics alone is appropriate for an early felon without abscess formation. The visible pus collection in this patient indicates abscess formation requiring drainage.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical presentation of localized digital pulp swelling with fluid collection indicates felon with abscess formation. This condition requires incision and drainage combined with oral antibiotics targeting Staphylococcus aureus, the most common pathogen in felons.

D) INCORRECT:

While hand surgery follow-up is recommended for reassessment, felon incision and drainage can be performed in the emergency department when indicated. Immediate consultation is not required for uncomplicated cases.

E) INCORRECT:

Radiographic evaluation may be considered to rule out retained foreign bodies but should not delay treatment of an established felon with abscess formation. Clinical diagnosis is sufficient to proceed with drainage.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female bartender presents with a three-day history of increasing pain, redness, and swelling of her right index finger. She reports frequently picking at her cuticles. She denies fever, chills, or other systemic symptoms. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F).  A photograph of the finger is shown. There are no ascending red streaks on the arm. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Obtain a plain radiograph of the digit
Prescribe a 7-day course of oral cephalexin
Incision and drainage of the affected area
Perform a partial nail plate avulsion
Instruct on warm water soaks and topical mupirocin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radiographs are used to evaluate for underlying osteomyelitis or a retained foreign body. These should be considered in cases of chronic, non-healing paronychia, a history of penetrating trauma, or concern for deep space infection. Given the acute three-day presentation and a superficial, localized abscess on examination, there is no clinical suspicion for bony involvement.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics like cephalexin are appropriate for treating the cellulitis associated with paronychia, especially if it is extensive or if the patient is immunocompromised. However, antibiotics alone have poor penetration into a mature abscess cavity. Without drainage, the infection is unlikely to resolve. Therefore, this is not the most appropriate initial step for a drainable abscess.

C) CORRECT:

The definitive and primary treatment for any localized, walled-off collection of pus is incision and drainage. This procedure relieves pressure, removes the infectious nidus, and provides immediate pain relief. For a simple paronychia, this can often be done by gently lifting the eponychial fold with a scalpel or large-gauge needle. In an immunocompetent patient with a localized infection and no significant surrounding cellulitis, incision and drainage alone is often curative and systemic antibiotics may not be necessary. Common causative organisms are Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes.

D) INCORRECT:

A partial or complete nail plate avulsion is a more invasive procedure indicated when the infection has tracked underneath the nail plate, forming a subungual abscess. This patient has a purulent collection at the lateral nail fold, not under the nail itself. Therefore, this procedure is not warranted at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Warm soaks and topical antibiotics are the first-line treatment for early, mild acute paronychia that presents only with cellulitis and without a drainable abscess. This patient's condition has progressed beyond this stage, as indicated by the presence of a fluctuant, purulent collection. This conservative approach is no longer sufficient and would delay definitive treatment.
questions.hint: This patient presents with acute paronychia complicated by abscess formation, as evidenced by the collection of purulent material.
